http://schema.org/paymentUrl.description: The URL for sending a payment.

http://schema.org/mainEntityOfPage.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described. See background notes for details. inverse property: mainEntity.

http://schema.org/unitCode.description: The unit of measurement given using the UN/CEFACT Common Code (3 characters) or a URL. Other codes than the UN/CEFACT Common Code may be used with a prefix followed by a colon.

http://schema.org/actionPlatform.description: The high level platform(s) where the Action can be performed for the given URL. To specify a specific application or operating system instance, use actionApplication.

http://schema.org/softwareRequirements.description: Component dependency requirements for application. This includes runtime environments and shared libraries that are not included in the application distribution package, but required to run the application (Examples: DirectX, Java or .NET runtime). Supersedes requirements.

http://schema.org/additionalType.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

http://schema.org/sameAs.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

http://schema.org/gameLocation.description: Real or fictional location of the game (or part of game).

http://schema.org/trackingUrl.description: Tracking url for the parcel delivery.

http://schema.org/fuelType.description: The type of fuel suitable for the engine or engines of the vehicle. If the vehicle has only one engine, this property can be attached directly to the vehicle.

http://schema.org/publishingPrinciples.description: Link to page describing the editorial principles of the organization primarily responsible for the creation of the CreativeWork.

http://schema.org/targetUrl.description: The URL of a node in an established educational framework.

http://schema.org/applicationCategory.description: Type of software application, e.g. "Game, Multimedia".

http://schema.org/contentUrl.description: Actual bytes of the media object, for example the image file or video file.

http://schema.org/discussionUrl.description: A link to the page containing the comments of the CreativeWork.

http://schema.org/codeRepository.description: Link to the repository where the un-compiled, human readable code and related code is located (SVN, github, CodePlex).

http://schema.org/isBasedOnUrl.description: A resource that was used in the creation of this resource. This term can be repeated for multiple sources. For example, http://example.com/great-multiplication-intro.html.

http://schema.org/replyToUrl.description: The URL at which a reply may be posted to the specified UserComment.

http://schema.org/vehicleTransmission.description: The type of component used for transmitting the power from a rotating power source to the wheels or other relevant component(s) ("gearbox" for cars).

http://schema.org/artworkSurface.description: The supporting materials for the artwork, e.g. Canvas, Paper, Wood, Board, etc. Supersedes surface.

http://schema.org/thumbnailUrl.description: A thumbnail image relevant to the Thing.

http://schema.org/installUrl.description: URL at which the app may be installed, if different from the URL of the item.

http://schema.org/prescribingInfo.description: Link to prescribing information for the drug.

http://schema.org/significantLink.description: One of the more significant URLs on the page. Typically, these are the non-navigation links that are clicked on the most. Supersedes significantLinks.

http://schema.org/artMedium.description: The material used. (e.g. Oil, Watercolour, Acrylic, Linoprint, Marble, Cyanotype, Digital, Lithograph, DryPoint, Intaglio, Pastel, Woodcut, Pencil, Mixed Media, etc.) Supersedes material.

http://schema.org/gamePlatform.description: The electronic systems used to play video games.

http://schema.org/hasMap.description: A URL to a map of the place. Supersedes map.

http://schema.org/image.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

http://schema.org/relatedLink.description: A link related to this web page, for example to other related web pages.

http://schema.org/genre.description: Genre of the creative work or group.

http://schema.org/labelDetails.description: Link to the drug's label details.

http://schema.org/screenshot.description: A link to a screenshot image of the app.

http://schema.org/ticketToken.description: Reference to an asset (e.g., Barcode, QR code image or PDF) usable for entrance.

http://schema.org/menu.description: Either the actual menu or a URL of the menu.

http://schema.org/artform.description: e.g. Painting, Drawing, Sculpture, Print, Photograph, Assemblage, Collage, etc.

http://schema.org/embedUrl.description: A URL pointing to a player for a specific video. In general, this is the information in the src element of an embed tag and should not be the same as the content of the loc tag.

http://schema.org/featureList.description: Features or modules provided by this application (and possibly required by other applications).

http://schema.org/schemaVersion.description: Indicates (by URL or string) a particular version of a schema used in some CreativeWork. For example, a document could declare a schemaVersion using a URL such as http://schema.org/version/2.0/ if precise indication of schema version was required by some application.

http://schema.org/propertyID.description: A commonly used identifier for the characteristic represented by the property, e.g. a manufacturer or a standard code for a property. propertyID can be(1) a prefixed string, mainly meant to be used with standards for product properties; (2) a site-specific, non-prefixed string (e.g. the primary key of the property or the vendor-specific id of the property), or (3)a URL indicating the type of the property, either pointing to an external vocabulary, or a Web resource that describes the property (e.g. a glossary entry).Standards bodies should promote a standard prefix for the identifiers of properties from their standards.

http://schema.org/license.description: A license document that applies to this content, typically indicated by URL.

http://schema.org/downloadUrl.description: If the file can be downloaded, URL to download the binary.

http://schema.org/releaseNotes.description: Description of what changed in this version.

http://schema.org/roleName.description: A role played, performed or filled by a person or organization. For example, the team of creators for a comic book might fill the roles named 'inker', 'penciller', and 'letterer'; or an athlete in a SportsTeam might play in the position named 'Quarterback'. Supersedes namedPosition.

http://schema.org/serviceUrl.description: The website to access the service.

http://schema.org/warning.description: Any FDA or other warnings about the drug (text or URL).

http://schema.org/applicationSubCategory.description: Subcategory of the application, e.g. "Arcade Game".

http://schema.org/acceptsReservations.description: Indicates whether a FoodEstablishment accepts reservations. Values can be Boolean, a URL at which reservations can be made or (for backwards compatibility) the strings Yes or No.
